												Imagine Me is agitated by its own existence. It can’t decide where to commit, patching on modes of play like a bad worker trying to explain their way out of a botched job by showing you all the little, trivial tasks they’ve completed instead. Right out of the gate Imagine Me tries its hand at procedurally generated level designs (it can’t be that hard, right? Everyone’s doing it). But once the algorithms start rolling and the levels actually come into existence, it’s immediately clear Imagine Me hasn’t the slightest clue what it’s doing.Chunks of familiar levels become hastily adjoined to one another into an unplayable mess of broken hitboxes and impenetrable block mazes. It’s chaos of the highest degree, silent caverns filled only with the cries of my broken soul as I beat myself against a metaphorical wall trying to beat a game which is quite literally impossible to complete. Somewhere along the development pipeline it must have been clear that something had gone horrible wrong, but rather than rework the disastrous level generator into something functional, Imagine Me instead decides to abandon it altogether and starts building levels by hand (it worked for Mario, didn’t it?).But much to my dismay Imagine Me hasn’t much of a knack for level designs, random or otherwise. At numerous points it almost appears as if whoever actually designed these levels fell asleep and never completed them, or otherwise became so bored with their own creation that they decided enough was enough and shipped whatever they had in front of them at the time. And thus we are left with 30 or so astoundingly dull and simplistic levels which play very much like the afterthought they were.I might feel worse about the depths of Imagine Me’s failure if it didn’t seem so apathetic toward aspiring to even moderate quality (or functionality). Everything feels empty and tedious, leading you in circles until either the game breaks or you stop playing. Imagine Me is sloppy and dysfunctional, but I couldn’t say it seems to actually care.You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

								According to Steam, I have only played the game for 15 minutes. That sounds about right. During that 15 minutes I have played through the entirety of the game. I then quit, while scratching my head and asking myself "What am I missing? There has to be something I'm overlooking here." After a little investigating it is clear that I did not miss anything, I really did 100% the game in 15 minutes. About 5 minutes of that time was spent pressing every button and key on my controller and keyboard trying to find hidden options or abilities that will help me beat the 75% of the "generated" levels that are literally unbeatable.The game consists of 8 "tutorial" levels that slowly introduce game mechanics of springs, keys, doors, and spikes. You will beat these levels in about 5 minutes if you take your time. After you are done with those, all you are left with is the "generated" levels. 75% of these "generated" levels (which are not actually generated, you will run into the same few levels over and over) are unbeatable due to the positioning of the exit door, and the lack of an actual game mechanic or player ability other than running and jumping. If you are lucky enough to end up in one of the winnable levels, then after you reach the exit door you will be kicked back out to the hub world where you can once again choose to play the tutorials again or another generated level. I have cycled through the generated levels several times, and I only counted 2 of them that are actually winnable. The game has no replayability, no interesting mechanics, and no redeeming factors. The sound is fine.Something important to note is that despite the Steam Store page for the game saying "Full Controller Support", the game does not use xInput (important to anyone using an Xbox controller or x360ce) and does not allow you to rebind keys. So you'll likely have the jump button be something ridiculous like a shoulder button on your controller.Don't buy this game for any price in its current state.5/5

Early Access Review
								I'm going to give Imagine Me a tentative recommendation, but that's on the premise that this is still an Early Access game, and I hope to see it expand (much) farther beyond what is currently here.Imagine Me is a pretty simple platformer where your goal is to get from start to finish in each room / level. Sometimes you need to unlock a door by collecting a key first, and sometimes you traverse portals. Spikes and scowling, flaming enemies are to be avoided. The levels are also sparsely populated with crates, random physics objects for which I could find no real purpose.As of this review, this game is a decent foundation for a much better game, but for now, it's only a handful of levels that provide a very low level of challenge. I like the idea of being able to craft levels for others, and being able to find out more about the game's protagonist by collecting snapshots is interesting, but it's all over so soon and you're left wanting more. The current set of "challenge levels" are a little uninspired.Here's to hoping Imagine Me will grow into something better. For now, only buy if you're really wanting a new, simple platforming experience and you want to support this game before its official release.

												This game is an endless loop of randomized levels that range from ridiculously easy, to weirdly difficult, to litterally impossible. There are glitches that can actually break gameplay, for example in the boss room with the ghost, sometimes the rotating platforms with just start drifting, eventually making it impossible to reach the exit. Dying, or just hitting respawn does not reset any level and you don't actually lose anything other than a few seconds of progress, so there are no death consequenses, however if a level breaks, in order to get free you'll have to actually quit to the main menu. When you return you get a different randomized level. The game just doesn't have any variety to it, even the boss levels don't feel that special. One boss even seem to be unkillable, taking over a dozen of my arrows without dying when the other bosses only took 3. exit was only blocked off by a single breakable wall though, so I just left without trying any further to kill the boss.After each level you get a little bit of the character's story. Once you get all parts of the story it just loops again. Every few levels you get a boss level, usually one with a ghost who teleport along the bottom of the room. There's no tell or warning to his teleports, he just pops randomly around, sometimes right on top of you, and every hit on you is a one hit kill.The hitboxes in the game are weird, some blocks you can just kinda pass through, the arrows you shoot move like half your walking speed and make a weird offkey piano chord when you pick more up, the graphics and animations look thrown together almost last minute with many back ground assets sticking out of the sides of the field and sometimes appearing on top of monsters who should be in the foreground...Overall it feels like an unfinished student project.

								EDITED Review first: OK, so as I promised, I have come back to try and replay this game and see what has been changed/improved. I find that a lot of things have indeed been overhauled and many improvements have been put in. There is more to the game to be sure and it plays a lot smoother for me. I can say with all honesty that the Dev took criticisms to heart and really tried with this one. It's simple but challenging. But I will caution you to read the reviews with an open mind before deciding to buy. As I mentioned originally it is basic but remember people, this is a small developer. It isn't the next Mario Bros game but it's not crap. Anyway, the long and the short of it is. You will either like it or not. Just go in eyes open. It has flaws but there is some fun there if you are fond of challenging games. Original Review.This is one of those games where early access is a bad thing. Like a lot of others, I received this in a bundle. I've played all of maybe 5 minutes of it and already uninstalling. It's not for me and unless there are major changes involved, it will never be for me. The jumping feels glitchy, the graphics aren't bad but as many have pointed out there is a HUGE problem with the level generation. Without more being added to the moveset then you will find many levels unbeatable. Now, that said, I am not bashing these devs or the game itself. In fact I am kind of curious to see what they plan on doing with it, if anything. As it stands now though I would not value this game at $9.99 or even $4.99. Stay away until the full game is out. Give it a chance at that time. Should things improve I will gladly look at it again. Just not that much to be enjoyed in its current state.
